Simple Exteriors, Complex Internal

We turn coffee into code, and code into client‚Äôs profits since 2009.
Basically alchemy, but with better ROI.

Let‚Äôs talk about your problems, how to use them on Tinder, and other useful things.

(We‚Äôre still working on turning code back into coffee. We‚Äôll keep you posted.)

The Value Proposition Nobody Asked For But Everyone Needs

One peculiar thing about modern business is the inverse relationship between the amount of software installed and the clarity of answers obtained. Companies somehow end up with seventeen different systems that don‚Äôt talk to each other, generating reports that answer questions nobody asked while ignoring the only two that matter: where are we losing money, and where could we be making more?

You‚Äôre probably here because:

  • Your company has more financial reports than employees, yet somehow less clarity
  • Every department head insists they‚Äôre wildly profitable (while your bank account is crying every day)
  • Your ERP system has a user manual longer than the Dodd-Frank Act
  • You‚Äôve built a thriving ecosystem of non-communicating software applications that would make biodiversity researchers proud
If you're running a business, managing one, or directing its IT, and you'd like to see your company's financial reality without the need for three accounting degrees and a shaman‚Äîwell, that's where we come in.

The Experience Section

Here‚Äôs the fundamental problem with the ERP and accounting software landscape: it was built by people who have never sweated over making payroll or explained a bad quarter to investors. They were solving the wrong problems. ‚ÄúLook, we can generate tons of impressive charts!‚Äù they proclaim, while CEOs quietly wonder why none of those charts answer the question ‚ÄúWhere is my money going?‚Äù

The disconnect is practically a law of nature. Most software is written by people who‚Äôve never run the businesses they‚Äôre writing for.

Since 2009, we‚Äôve been doing something peculiar: making financial software that actually makes sense. We started with mom-and-pop shops and now serve companies with market caps that would make a decent SPAC acquisition. Actually talking to entrepreneurs‚Äîthousands of brutally honest conversations about their daily struggles, late-night anxieties, and the information they desperately need but can‚Äôt extract from their expensive software. While Silicon Valley was busy creating apps that help you share photos of your lunch, we were building algorithms that help you afford lunch in the first place.

From our Dubai headquarters, we blend Middle Eastern business acumen with Silicon Valley innovation approaches. Imagine if Sheikh Zayed and Steve Jobs had a tech baby with a finance degree. That‚Äôs essentially us, but with a better understanding of your balance sheet and considerably less turtleneck sweaters.

Worst Practices (A Field Guide)

Over time, we‚Äôve noticed some recurring errors in business operations that would make any financial analyst cringe:

  • Time isn‚Äôt on the balance sheet‚Äîthough it‚Äôs often your scarcest resource (and unlike money, you can‚Äôt raise more of it in a Series B)
  • Profit calculations that would make Enron‚Äôs accountants nervous‚Äîdepartments show profits while the company loses money, a mathematical impossibility that somehow persists
  • Internal transfer pricing that would confuse a tax haven specialist‚Äîmaking it impossible to know which business units are subsidizing others
  • Forecasts based on historical data‚Äîlike driving forward while looking exclusively in the rearview mirror
  • When problems arise, no one knows how to respond (so they just keep losing money)‚Äîlike watching a slow-motion train wreck while the conductor debates which button to press

Looks familiar, right? The good news is that these problems are so universal you can use them as a conversation starter on Tinder. (‚ÄúSo, how many times does your paper profit in board reports exceed your actual profit?‚Äù works surprisingly well.)

The even better news is that solutions exist. And not just any solutions‚Äîones that don‚Äôt require a PhD in financial engineering or the patience of a central bank regulator.

The Value Proposition (Our Term Sheet)

We don‚Äôt just think outside the box. We securitize the box, optimize its cash flows, and then distribute the returns to stakeholders. Our approach:

  • Profit forensics‚Äîwe find where money goes to die in your organization, like a financial CSI team
  • Margin automation‚Äîbecause profitable processes should run themselves, like a well-structured perpetuity
  • Real-time decision support‚Äîgiving executives the information equivalent of insider trading, except it‚Äôs legal and about their own company

If you‚Äôre looking for software that‚Äôs powerful enough to run a hedge fund but simple enough that you won‚Äôt need to hire quants to operate it, you‚Äôve found it.

Welcome to the future of business software. It‚Äôs sophisticated yet approachable, like a financial model that doesn‚Äôt require sixteen tabs of assumptions to make sense.

Would you like to start generating alpha through better information? Or would you prefer to continue with your current approach, which has roughly the same expected return as a savings account in an inflationary environment? (That‚Äôs what we in finance call a ‚Äúleading question.‚Äù)
